intro: Gaylussacia pseudovaccinium, commonly known as the swamp cranberry, is a shrub native to the eastern United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its low-growing habit and dense foliage. The plant produces small, bright red berries that are edible but often have a tart flavor. It thrives in acidic, wet soils and is commonly found in bogs and swamps. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
